name: Bring me to life
description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

constellations_primary.name: Bring me to life
constellations_primary.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

start.title: Barbie
start.creator_credit: Greta Gerwig, Jacqueline Durran, Nick Houy, David Heyman, Margot Robbie, Robbie Brenner, Tom Ackerley, Heyday Films, LuckyChap Entertainment, Mattel, NB/GG Pictures, Sarah Greenwood and Noah Baumbach
start.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2023
start.brief_description: Barbie and Ken are having the time of their lives in the colorful and seemingly perfect world of Barbie Land. However, when they get a chance to go to the real world, they soon discover the joys and perils of living among humans.

constellations_other.name: Pink subversions
constellations_other.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

end.title: Superstar: The Karen Carpenter Story
end.creator_credit: Todd Haynes, Gina Garan, Cynthia Schneider and Iced Tea Productions
end.brief_description: The final 17 years of American singer and musician Karen Carpenter, performed almost entirely by modified Barbie dolls.

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

links.description: Like Barbie, Todd Haynes’s experimental documentary Superstar: The Karen Carpenter Story draws on the iconic Barbie doll in his film to highlight unrealistic standards and pressures placed upon women, particularly those in the spotlight.

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

end.title: Barbie
end.creator_credit: Greta Gerwig, Jacqueline Durran, Nick Houy, David Heyman, Margot Robbie, Robbie Brenner, Tom Ackerley, Heyday Films, LuckyChap Entertainment, Mattel, NB/GG Pictures, Sarah Greenwood and Noah Baumbach
end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2023
end.brief_description: Barbie and Ken are having the time of their lives in the colorful and seemingly perfect world of Barbie Land. However, when they get a chance to go to the real world, they soon discover the joys and perils of living among humans.

constellations_other.name: Pink subversions
constellations_other.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

constellations_other.name: Retro aesthetics and feminine experiences
constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilised in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

links.description: Two parents magically become their child’s hand-made dolls and must work together to become human again in the videogame It Takes Two. Similarly dolls Barbie and Ken in Barbie magically become human as they travel to the real world.

start.title: Alice
start.creator_credit: Jan Svankmajer, Peter-Christian Fueter, Condor Features, Film Four International and Hessischer Rundfunk
start.brief_description: In a wonderland populated by an array of superbly animated puppets, steaks crawl, rolls sprout nails and Alice (the only human in the film), not only shrinks, but becomes her own doll. Czech surrealist Jan Svankmajer’s definitive version of “Alice’s adventures in Wonderland” is a distinctive vision which remains true to the absurd and menacing spirit of Lewis Carroll’s work.

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

links.description: Like the character Pinocchio in Guillermo del Toro’s Pinocchio, the hand-made doll May in the videogame It Takes Two is constructed of wood and similarly comes to life in the story.

start.title: Guillermo del Toro's Pinocchio
start.creator_credit: Guillermo del Toro, Mark Gustafson, Holly Klein, Ken Schretzmann, Alexander Bulkley, Corey Campodonico, Gary Ungar, Lisa Henson, Double Dare You, ShadowMachine, The Jim Henson Company, Curt Enderle, Guy Davis, Karla Castañeda and Patrick McHale
start.brief_description: During the rise of fascism in Mussolini’s Italy, a wooden boy brought magically to life struggles to live up to his father’s expectations.

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

end.title: Alice
end.creator_credit: Jan Svankmajer, Peter-Christian Fueter, Condor Features, Film Four International and Hessischer Rundfunk
end.brief_description: In a wonderland populated by an array of superbly animated puppets, steaks crawl, rolls sprout nails and Alice (the only human in the film), not only shrinks, but becomes her own doll. Czech surrealist Jan Svankmajer’s definitive version of “Alice’s adventures in Wonderland” is a distinctive vision which remains true to the absurd and menacing spirit of Lewis Carroll’s work.

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

links.description: Like Guillermo del Toro’s Pinocchio, Jan Švankmajer’s Alice uses stop-motion animation to adapt a children’s fantasy novel where a doll plays the titular role.

start.title: Labyrinth
start.creator_credit: Jim Henson, Eric Rattray and Lucasfilm, Ltd.
start.brief_description: Take a journey into the Labyrinth, where nothing is as it seems. Sarah (Jennifer Connelly) spends most of her time play-acting scenes from her favourite book, The Labyrinth, or baby-sitting her younger brother, Toby. One night, frustrated with Toby’s incessant crying, she begs the goblins to take him away. When Toby actually disappears, Sarah follows him into the world of the wicked Goblin King (David Bowie), where she is given thirteen hours to conquer the Labyrinth, before her baby brother is turned into a goblin forever. An engaging fantasy film, populated by creatures created by Jim Henson’s Creature Shop, and drawing inspiration from a number of sources, including the works of Brian Froud, Maurice Sendak and M. C. Escher. Includes a special behind-the-scenes featurette detailing the making of Labyrinth.

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

end.title: Guillermo del Toro's Pinocchio
end.creator_credit: Guillermo del Toro, Mark Gustafson, Holly Klein, Ken Schretzmann, Alexander Bulkley, Corey Campodonico, Gary Ungar, Lisa Henson, Double Dare You, ShadowMachine, The Jim Henson Company, Curt Enderle, Guy Davis, Karla Castañeda and Patrick McHale
end.brief_description: During the rise of fascism in Mussolini’s Italy, a wooden boy brought magically to life struggles to live up to his father’s expectations.

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

links.description: Jim Henson directed the musical fantasy film Labyrinth, as well as producing it through his production company. Jim Henson Company went onto later produce a similarly darker children’s film Guillermo del Toro’s Pinocchio.

constellations_primary.name: Bring me to life
constellations_primary.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

end.creator_credit: Jim Henson, Eric Rattray and Lucasfilm, Ltd.

Sarah (Jennifer Connelly) spends most of her time play-acting scenes from her favourite book, The Labyrinth, or baby-sitting her younger brother, Toby. One night, frustrated with Toby’s incessant crying, she begs the goblins to take him away. An engaging fantasy film, populated by creatures created by Jim Henson’s Creature Shop, and drawing inspiration from a number of sources, including the works of Brian Froud, Maurice Sendak and M. C. Escher. Includes a special behind-the-scenes featurette detailing the making of Labyrinth.

constellations_other.name: Bring me to life
constellations_other.description: From the imaginative children’s show Lift Off!, explore the various ways dolls and puppets are connected and come to life on screen.

links.description: Before constructing puppets such as the doll EC in Lift Off!, Australian artist Ron Mueck worked on Labyrinth. Mueck not only designed, but also performed and voiced the character Ludo in the film.
